title: Steps of Service — Overview
objective: Understand the full service flow and the standards we use to deliver consistent hospitality.

blocks.label: Big Idea
blocks.text: Great service is not about perfection — it’s about consistency, timing, and care.

blocks.title: Core Standards
bullets: Be proactive with refills and needs
Control pacing (don’t let the table control you)
Communicate early with kitchen/bar when something is off

blocks.text: Your job is to make the guest feel taken care of — even when things go wrong.

title: Step 1: Greeting & First Impression
objective: Greet quickly, establish trust, and set the tone for the meal.

blocks.title: Timing Standard
bullets: If you’re slammed: acknowledge the table immediately

blocks.title: What to Do
bullets: Introduce yourself + confirm guest needs quickly
Set expectations if needed (e.g., 'I’ll be right back with drinks')

blocks.label: Save Line (when busy)
blocks.text: “Hey everyone — welcome in! I’m [Name]. I see you and I’ll be right back in just a moment to get you started.”

blocks.title: Common Mistakes
bullets: Rushing so hard the guest feels ignored

title: Step 2: Beverages & Getting Set Up
objective: Start the meal smoothly by getting drinks and setting the table up for success.

blocks.title: What to Do
bullets: Take beverage order (cocktails, wine, NA options)
Suggest 1–2 easy options if guests hesitate
Drop necessary items: napkins, share plates, extra settings when appropriate

blocks.title: Upsell Without Being Weird
bullets: Offer a specific suggestion (not a generic “do you want drinks?”)
Read the table (business dinner vs celebration vs quick bite)

blocks.label: Example
blocks.text: “If you’d like a cocktail, our [house cocktail] is super popular — or I can do a crisp Sauvignon Blanc if you’re thinking wine.”

title: Step 3: Menu Guidance & Guest Support
objective: Help guests order confidently with clear, accurate recommendations.

blocks.title: Recommendation Formula
bullets: Ask one quick question (protein, spice, lighter/heavier)

blocks.label: Example
blocks.text: “If you want something lighter, I’d do the [dish]. It’s bright, fresh, and really popular.”

blocks.title: Allergy Standard
bullets: Mark it in POS + verbally confirm with kitchen when needed

title: Step 4: Order Taking & Confirmation
objective: Take accurate orders, confirm details, and set expectations.

blocks.title: How to Take Orders Cleanly
bullets: Start with seat order when possible
Repeat back key details (temps, mods, allergies)
Confirm pacing if needed (apps before entrées, etc.)

blocks.title: What to Say
bullets: “Great — I’m going to repeat that back to make sure I have it perfect.”
“Any allergies or dietary restrictions I should know about?”

blocks.label: Accuracy Rule
blocks.text: Slow is smooth. Smooth is fast. Taking 10 extra seconds prevents a 10-minute problem.

title: Step 5: Course Control & Pacing
objective: Control timing so guests aren’t rushed or waiting too long.

blocks.title: Your Job: Control the Pace
bullets: Communicate with expo/kitchen when pacing matters
Avoid long dead gaps (guests get irritated)

blocks.title: Pacing Tools
bullets: Hold entrées if guests want time
Fire entrées when apps hit the table (if your kitchen uses coursing)
Ask: “Would you like a little break after apps or keep it rolling?”

blocks.text: A server who controls timing feels calm. A server who reacts to timing feels chaotic.

title: Step 6: Checkbacks & Table Touches
objective: Check in at the right moments without hovering, and fix issues early.

blocks.title: Timing Standard
bullets: Touch the table when you see a natural moment

blocks.label: Better than “Is everything okay?”
blocks.text: “How are we doing over here — can I grab anything for you?”

title: Step 7: Table Maintenance & Presence
objective: Keep the table clean, refreshed, and comfortable throughout the meal.

blocks.title: Non-Negotiables
bullets: Refresh drinks before they are empty
Be visible (guests should know you’re around)

blocks.title: Pre-bus Timing
bullets: Clear plates when everyone is finished (don’t rush one guest)

title: Step 8: Dessert & After-Dinner
objective: Offer a satisfying finish and increase check averages naturally.

blocks.title: When to Offer
bullets: When guests slow down and relax

blocks.title: How to Offer (Easy)
bullets: Suggest coffee/after-dinner drink pairing if appropriate

blocks.label: Example
blocks.text: “Are we saving room for dessert? The [dessert] is our favorite — and I can do espresso or coffee with it.”

title: Step 9: Check Drop & Payment
objective: Close out smoothly without rushing guests or making payment awkward.

blocks.title: When to Drop the Check
bullets: When guests signal they’re winding down
If guests ask for it — immediately

blocks.title: Payment Standards
bullets: Pick up the check presenter promptly
Confirm splits before running payment when possible

blocks.text: Fast payment = guests feel respected. Slow payment = guests feel trapped.

title: Step 10: Farewell & Reset
objective: End strong, invite them back, and reset for the next guest.

blocks.title: Farewell Standard
bullets: Use eye contact and a confident goodbye

title: Suggestive Selling (Warm, Not Pushy)

bullets: Make suggestions like a host, not a salesperson

During ordering: 1 appetizer that fits the table vibe
At entrées: 1 side/add-on that pairs naturally

blocks.text: “If you want to round it out, I’d add a side — it pairs really well with that and makes the meal feel complete.”

title: Mods & Substitutions (Protect the Guest + the Kitchen)

blocks.title: Default Approach
bullets: Be honest when it’s not possible
Offer a strong alternative when you can

blocks.title: Before You Say Yes
bullets: Does it change the core of the dish?

blocks.label: Best line
blocks.text: “Let me confirm with the kitchen so I can give you the right answer.”

blocks.title: Quality Guardrails
bullets: Don’t stack multiple heavy mods on one dish
Verbally alert expo for allergies or complicated requests

title: Pairing Defaults (Easy Wins)
objective: Make pairing suggestions that feel natural and confident — especially with seafood + wood-fire.

blocks.title: Harbor & Ember Pairing Defaults
bullets: Seafood + citrus/herbs → crisp white (Sauv Blanc / Albariño / Pinot Grigio)
Smoky/wood-fired meats → medium red (Pinot Noir / Grenache / lighter Cab blends)
Rich/creamy sauces → higher acid wine (Sauv Blanc / Chardonnay with acid) or citrusy cocktail
Spicy → slightly sweet or lower alcohol options

blocks.label: Safe Script
blocks.text: “If you’re doing seafood, a crisp white is a great win — it keeps everything bright and clean.”

title: Confidence Scripts (What to Say at the Table)
objective: Use ready-to-go language that matches our vibe and keeps service moving.

blocks.title: When guests ask: “What’s your favorite?”
bullets: “If you want coastal and fresh, I’d do [COASTAL FAVORITE] — it’s bright and super popular.”
“If you want something wood-fired and hearty, [WOOD-FIRED FAVORITE] is the move — smoky, satisfying, and consistent.”

blocks.title: When guests ask: “What’s popular?”
bullets: “Our most ordered are [TOP SELLER 1] and [TOP SELLER 2] — both are always strong.”

blocks.title: When guests ask: “Is it spicy?”
bullets: “That one definitely has heat — if you want no spice, I’d switch you to [NO-HEAT ALT].”

bullets: “Great question — let me confirm so I can answer accurately.”

A script you repeat to every table

Avoid the table until you find out later

title: POS Basics — Overview

bullets: Confirm allergy and severity with guest

Follow up with guest: “We confirmed that with the kitchen.”

Course timing prevents rushed meals and long waits

objective: Handle payment quickly and confidently so guests feel respected and not “stuck.”

blocks.title: Payment Standards
bullets: Confirm method: card vs cash vs split BEFORE running when possible

blocks.title: Best Practice Language

Ring shared items intentionally (and know your restaurant’s policy)
